data.subject: behavior
data.desc: The Painted Lady Butterfly (Vanessa Cardui) is known for its distinct migratory behavior[1]. They tend to inhabit sunny, brightly lit, open environments and are often attracted to open areas of flowers and clovers2. Adults spend time in small depressions in the ground on overcast days[2]. Vanessa cardui is extremely adaptable and thus can prosper in its niche in any of these environments[3]. Painted Ladies can be found at all elevations during migration but are usually found at elevations as low as sea level year-round, even during non-migratory time3. When the butterflies are found in large numbers, they can do serious damage to soybean crops[4].

data.subject: habits
data.desc: The Painted Lady Butterfly (Vanessa Cardui) inhabits backyards and meadows throughout most of the world[1]. They tend to inhabit sunny, brightly lit, open environments and are often attracted to open areas of flowers and clovers[2]. Adults spend time in small depressions in the ground on overcast days[2]. These medium-sized butterflies can cover a lot of ground, up to 100 miles per day during their migrations[3]. A painted lady is capable of reaching a speed of nearly 30 miles per hour[3]. Painted ladies reach northern areas well ahead of some of their more famous migrating cousins, like monarch butterflies[3].

data.subject: nesting
data.desc: The Painted Lady Butterfly (Vanessa Cardui) does not build nests as they are not social insects. They are solitary insects and do not live in colonies.

data.subject: breeding
data.desc: The breeding season of Vanessa Cardui takes place year-round, except in cooler areas where it stops in the fall and winter[1]. The average number of eggs per season is around 5001. The gestation period ranges from 20 to 25 days[1]. The age at sexual or reproductive maturity for both males and females ranges from 5 to 7 days[1].

data.subject: habitat
data.desc: Vanessa Cardui tend to inhabit sunny, brightly lit, open environments and are often attracted to open areas of flowers and clovers[1]. They establish territories within areas sheltered by hedgerows1. Adults spend time in small depressions in the ground on overcast days[1]. Vanessa Cardui can be found in fallow land, fields, gardens, ruderal areas, and waysides[2]. They are extremely adaptable and thus can survive in any of these environments[2]. Painted Ladies can be found at all elevations during migration but are usually found at elevations as low as sea level year-round, even during the non-migratory time[2]. Vanessa cardui lives on all continents except Australia and Antarctica and is the most widely distributed butterfly in the world[3].

data.subject: perception
data.desc: I’m sorry but I couldn’t find any information about people’s general perception of Vanessa Cardui in Denmark or other countries. However, Vanessa Cardui is one of the most widely distributed species of butterfly and can be found on all continents except Antarctica and Australia[1]. They live in most biogeographic regions, including Nearctic, Palearctic, Neotropical, Ethiopian, Oriental, and Oceanic Islands[1]. The species is resident only in warmer areas but migrates in spring, and sometimes again in autumn[2].

data.subject: culture
data.desc: I’m sorry but I couldn’t find any information about cultural significance of Vanessa Cardui in Denmark or any other countries, cultures, or religions. However, Vanessa Cardui is a pollinator of the plants and flowers in its habitat[1]. More than 100 plants have been recorded to act as hosts for Painted Lady larvae, but the most common include thistles, hollyhock, mallow, milkweed, aster, and a variety of legumes[1]. Vanessa cardui tend to inhabit sunny, brightly lit, open environments and are often attracted to open areas of flowers and clovers[2].

data.subject: benefits
data.desc: According to Animal Diversity Web, Vanessa cardui assists with pollination; with pollination comes more plants and thus more oxygen. The presence of butterflies also indicates a healthy environment, so changes in populations can lead to exploration and research of habitats and ecosystems by scientists[1]. Butterflies are also an important species to study, since changes in butterfly populations can show that there are changes in the ecosystem[2].

According to Animal Diversity Web, Vanessa cardui is a pollinator of the plants and flowers in its habitat. More than 100 plants have been recorded to act as hosts for Painted Lady larvae, but the most common include thistles, hollyhock, mallow, milkweed, aster, and a variety of legumes[1]. Therefore, if you want your building design to have a positive impact on Vanessa Cardui, you should consider planting these plants in your building’s vicinity.
